items.dose: Please, consult a paediatric TB expert for dosing of neonates and infants weighing below 4 kg.

4to7.note:
• This table does not provide a complete treatment plan. For more information on a regimen (e.g., eligibility, duration, potential modifications, adverse events, monitoring), please refer to the relevant WHO Operational Handbook 
(https://tbksp.org/en/implementation-books-solr)
 • dt = dispersible tablet. The concentration in mg/ml shown under Formulation is achieved when the tablet is dissolved in 10 ml of water. Each dispersible tablet should be dissolved in a minimum of 10 ml drinking water; the maximum volume of water recommended for dispersion of a dose is 50 ml. If multiple dispersible tablets are given together they may be dissolved in the same solution to reduce volume.

Each dispersible tablet should be dissolved in a minimum of 10 ml drinking water; the maximum volume of water recommended for dispersion of a dose is 50 ml. If multiple dispersible tablets are given together they may be dissolved in the same solution to reduce volume.
• The concentration in mg/ml shown under Formulation is achieved when the tablet is dissolved in 10 ml of water. For these formulations, the number of ml under Quantity reflects the amount of solution to give to administer the required mg dose. If adult tablets are used these have to be crushed and dispersed. The bioavailability of dissolved, crushed adult tablets is uncertain for most medicines and the use of dispersible tablets is preferred.
• *If high-dose isoniazid is being added to the regimen use the dose schedule at
 (https://extranet.who.int/tbknowledge/en/node/637)

• *If high-dose isoniazid is being added to the regimen use the dose schedule at
 (https://extranet.who.int/tbknowledge/en/node/637)

items.tabs:
400 mg once daily for 2 weeks, then 200 mg 3 times per week afterwards
 OR 
200 mg daily for 8 weeks, then 100 mg daily afterwards

remarks: • This table does not provide a complete treatment plan. For more information on a regimen (e.g., eligibility, duration, potential modifications, adverse events, monitoring), please refer to the relevant WHO Operational Handbook (https://tbksp.org/en/implementation-books-solr).
• The standard duration of BPaLM/BPaL is 6 months (26 weeks). BPaL can be extended to a total of 9 months (39 weeks) if treatment response is slow.
• Bedaquiline 100 mg tablets may be taken whole or crushed and dispersed in water before administration (this does not reduce their absorption by the body).

9monthoral.remarks:
• This table does not provide a complete treatment plan. For more information on a regimen (e.g., eligibility, duration, potential modifications, adverse events, monitoring), please refer to the relevant WHO Operational Handbook (https://tbksp.org/en/implementation-books-solr).
• dt = dispersible tablet. The concentration in mg/ml shown under Formulation is achieved when the tablet is dissolved in 10 ml of water. Each dispersible tablet should be dissolved in a minimum of 10 ml drinking water; the maximum volume of water recommended for dispersion of a dose is 50 ml. If multiple dispersible tablets are given together they may be dissolved in the same solution to reduce volume.
• The concentration in mg/ml shown under Formulation is achieved when the tablet is dissolved in 10 ml of water. For these formulations, the number of ml under Quantity reflects the amount of solution to give to administer the required mg dose. If adult tablets are used these have to be crushed and dispersed. The bioavailability of dissolved, crushed adult tablets is uncertain for most medicines and the use of dispersible tablets is preferred.
• Bedaquiline 100 mg tablets may be taken whole or crushed and dispersed in water before administration (this does not reduce their absorption by the body).
• Clofazimine tablets dissolve slowly in water over 5 minutes. Use 5 mL and 10 mL of water for 50 mg and 100 mg tablets, respectively. Stir prior to administration.

longerregimen.remarks:
• This table does not provide a complete treatment plan. For more information on a regimen (e.g., eligibility, duration, potential modifications, adverse events, monitoring), please refer to the relevant WHO Operational Handbook (https://tbksp.org/en/implementation-books-solr).
• dt = dispersible tablet. The concentration in mg/ml shown under Formulation is achieved when the tablet is dissolved in 10 ml of water. Each dispersible tablet should be dissolved in a minimum of 10 ml drinking water; the maximum volume of water recommended for dispersion of a dose is 50 ml. If multiple dispersible tablets are given together they may be dissolved in the same solution to reduce volume.
• The concentration in mg/ml shown under Formulation is achieved when the tablet is dissolved in 10 ml of water. For these formulations, the number of ml under Quantity reflects the amount of solution to give to administer the required mg dose. If adult tablets are used these have to be crushed and dispersed. The bioavailability of dissolved, crushed adult tablets is uncertain for most medicines and the use of dispersible tablets is preferred.
• Bedaquiline 100 mg tablets may be taken whole or crushed and dispersed in water before administration (this does not reduce their absorption by the body).
• Delamanid 50 mg tablets may be taken whole or crushed and dispersed in water before administration (this does not reduce their absorption by the body).
• Clofazimine tablets dissolve slowly in water over 5 minutes. Use 5 mL and 10 mL of water for 50 mg and 100 mg tablets, respectively. Stir prior to administration.
